div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

Port Said to London Via Brindisi
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from Port Said to London via Brindiri or via Marseilles £25.9.11.

div.head: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.
div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

div.head: RED SEA LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.

Approved bills discounted.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday was a summer's day in the early part, but at 1p.m. the wind suddenly veered to the N.E. giving every appearance of rain and squally weather. Shortly after, however, it backed again to the westward in shower of rain, and by 9p.m. a dead calm prevailed. There was a clear sky and the night was beautiful. Barometer high and rising.

div.head: THE NILE
div.p: We have already alluded to the recent observations of Sir William Preece relative to the neglected condition of the Nile, but both by reason of the importance of the topic discussed, no less than on account of the professional position of the lecturer, it deserves fuller consideratino, as it possesses for dwellers in Eygpt an absorbing interest. The Nile is the most precious gift bestowed by a bounteous Providence upon this favored land, and every means which practical science can suggest should be employed to utilise to the fullest possible extent the purposes it is intended to serve. The P.W.D. has, up to the present, been regarded by common consent as comprising a body of highly trained and experienced experts of which any country might be proud, and upon whose judgment the public has been in the habit of placing absolute and unquestioning reliance. To the initiative and capacity of this department we owe the conception and accomplishment of one of the grandest engineering feats which the modern world has witnessed. But it may reasonably be asked whether the preservation of the river’s depth at its normal and requisite level, the maintenance of its banks in an efficient state of repair, and the counteracting of its dangerous and impeding currents between Assouan and Alexandria, is not a duty which, though far more modest and less imposing than the erection of dams and reservoirs, is equally essential of fulfilment Can it be that we have been sleeping the sleep of the seven sleepers all this while, only to be rudely awakened by the clarion tones of Sir William’s perturbing though timely warning? Has the idol that we have so long venerated nothing but feet of clay, which his well-directed blows have shattered to atoms? Englishmen, to whatever class they belong, are, as a rule, slow to condemn. Their inborn and unquenchable love of justice and fair-play operates as an effective curb upon their impulses. Their strong sense of gratitude likewise makes them prone to look with leniency upon the shortcomings of those who have rendered faithful service to the public. It is, on the other hand, hard to believe that Sir William Preece has been guilty of mere wanton fault finding, and it is still harder to conceive that he should allow himself to give utterance to a hasty censure. Regard for his own professional reputation would, presumably, have restrained him from hazarding opinions formed without a due and accurate knowledge of all the facts. Taking all these circumstances into account, it is but natural that his strictures should hate evoked a feeling of anxiety. Nothing will allay the uneasiness of the public but a clear and conclusive refutation of his charges of neglect, pronounced by experts of equal eminence and independence, and to this end a committee of investigation should be forthwith appointed whose standing and impartiality could not reasonably be challenged.

div.head: Russian Raids
div.p: THE PEACE REPORTS
Tokio, February 22.
300 Russians raiders slightly damaged the railway between Hai-chen and Taschichia on the 20th inst. They again disregarded the neutrality of the country to the west of the Liao. (Reuter.
London, February 22.

The Japanese funds rose 1 1/4 upon the peace reports. It appears certain that Russia has nut Actually proposed any terms, but yesterday evening’s telegram is regarded as reflecting the views of the increasingly influential peace party.
Baron Suyematsu pronounces the terms as preposterous as they leave Russia the gainer.
(Reuter.)
Tokio, February 22.
The Government has ordered 25 torpedo destroyers to be built. (Havas.)
Tientsin, February 22.
Twenty Japanese torpedo-boats have arrived from the island of Formosa.(Havas.)

div.head: STORES FOR THE RUSSIANS
div.p: LANDED AT DJIBOUTI.
London, February 22.
A French steamer has landed quantities of stores and dynamite for the Russians prin­cipally at Djibouti and Diego Suarez. (R )

div.head: NORTH SEA ENQUIRY
div.p: COMMISSIONERS’ REPORT COMPLETED.
Paris, February 22.

The North Sea Commissioners have completed their report. It will probably be published on Saturday. It does not discuss the question of the presence or absence of the torpedo-boats. It declares that Admiral Rodjestvensky might legitimately have believed that his squadron was endangered, and was entitled in those circumstances to act as he did. The report takes note of Russia’s undertaking to indemnify the victims. (Reuter.)

div.head: SITUATION IN BAKU
div.p: STREETS FILLED WITH CORPSES.
Baku, February 22.
Sanguinary encounters are taking place every day.(Havas.)
London, February 22.
A laconic telegram from Baku states that all offices are closed, and that the streets are filled with corpses. (Reuter.)
Warsaw, February 22.
It is feared there will be a general strike of railwaymen. (Havas.)

div.head: HOUSE OF COMMONS
div.p: THE IRISH QUESTION.
London, February 22.
House of Commons.—Mr. Redmond’s amend­ment was rejected by 286 votes against 246.
In the course of the debate, Sir H. Campbell- Bannerman said that he still continued to support the policy of a thorough fundamental alteration in the whole system of Irish government.

div.head: GOVERNMENT OF MACEDONIA
div.p: LORD LANSDOWNE'S SCHEME.
London, February 22.

In connection with the unsatisfactory condition of the Balkans, as mentioned in the King's Speech, Lord Lansdowne has submitted to some of the Powers a scheme for the govern­ment of Macedonia by a European Commission, which would reform the country, the Porte retaining the right to appoint a Governor- General. The Powers are at present discussing the Austro-Russian financial reform proposals.
(Reuter.)

The capital is more than three millions sterling and the factories will give employment to seven thousand persons. Other mills projected will employ about two thousand operatives.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Sabet Palace, the sale of which we announced yesterday, has been purchased for L.E. 65,000.
A.L.M. & D.S.—The society is giving a grand concert at the New Khedivial Hotel next Wednesday evening.
Land Deal.—Boutros Pasha Ghali, it is said, has disposed of his estates in Upper Egypt to an English company for L.E.240,000.
Yachting.—The steam yacht “Iolaire” has not arrived at Alexandria yet, as announced yesterday. The yacht at present in the harbour is the “Doris.”

Bound to India. — The “Fraser,” a large coast-guard cruiser for the Indian Government, arrived at Port Said on Tuesday afternoon. She was built by Messrs. Armstrong & Co., of Newcastle, and is bound for Calcutta.

Trial of Incendiary. — The trial of the young native, Chaiabi, who is accused of having set on fire the lodgings of his mistress, the celebrated Arab singer, Sairafieh, was to have come before the Cairo Native Court on Monday, but the hearing has been postponed until March 4.

Merchant Seamen’s Home.—A concert has been arranged by Mrs. J. Roberts to take place at the Merchant Seamen's Home to-morrow evening at 8.30. The following have kindly consented to take part: Rev. R. Wormed, Messrs. W. Sarjeant, J. Purvis, P. Sinith, Mrs. and Miss MunGavin, and Mrs. J. Roberts.

Alhambra Theatre.—A new ballet, “Les Aventures d un Brigand,” is to be produced uns evening. To morrow a special performance will be given in honor of the Italian "première danseuse.” Masked balls will be, given on Saturday. The performances of the "Chat Noir" will take place at the Alhambra on the 4th, 5th, 6th, ana 7th March.

Khedivial Agricultural Society.—A trial of steam ploughs, diggers, &c., will be held tomorrow at 3.30 p.m. on the property of Boghos Fasha Nubar at Shoubra under the auspices of the Khedival Agricultural Society. Members of the society are invited to be present. A special tram will leave Shoubra for Cairo at 5.30 p.m.

The Cotton Trade.— In his cotton trade circular, issued last week, Mr. William Tattersall gives a list of thirty new cotton-spinning mills which are being built in Lancashire. The capital is more than three millions sterling,and the factories will give employment to seven thousand persons. Other mills projected will employ about two thousand operatives.

A Magnificent Carpet, of Turkish hand manufacture, has been bought from Messrs. T. A. Spartali and Co. by Mr. Emmanuel Benachi and is being exhibited for a few days at Messrs. Chaion’s establishment in Chern Pasha-street, Alexandria. The fineness of the workmanship is remarkable. Messrs. Spartali’s exhibition of carpets in Old Bourse-street will remain open until the 28th inst.

“Alexandrie en Baisse” is the title of a new “revue,” which is shortly to be produced at the Alhambra Theatre. The revue is by Mr. George Ralli, the author of the two former Alexandrian revues, "Alexandrie qui Marche" and “Alexandrie Rigole,” which have been given at the Alhambra. A recent scandal, in which a wealthy Pasha of Alexandria has played a conspicuous part, is to be one of the up-to-date topics treated in the revue.

Tourist Steamers.—Readers of this paper will observe in our advertising columns parti­culars of the sailings of the White Star Line from Alexandria to Naples (reached in four days) and America. This service is undoubtedly one of the best for reaching Europe and should be well patronised by the many travellers now in Egypt, who will soon be contemplating their return journey. The immediate sailings are : “Canopic” (13,000tons) March 9; ‘‘Republic” (15,400tons) March 16 ; “Romanic" (11,400tons) March 30, and the fares front Alexandria to Naples are £10 and upwards Bookings may be effected at the White Star agents in Alexandria, Messrs. J. Ross and Co., and at Cook’s tourist offices, in Cairo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. E. the Governor of Alexandria returned from Cairo yesterday.

The festivities in connection with the marriage of Youssef Pasha Talaat’s daughter, with Mustapha Bey Zohni commenced last Friday and will last a week. The Duke and Duchess of Connaught were among the distinguished guests yesterday evening.
Local Lewa the Hon. M. G. Talbot Pasha, Director of Sudan Surveys, and Nason Pasha, secretary-general of the Civil Administration, have been promoted to the rank of Lewa.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT
div.p: DATE OF DEPARTURE

The Duke and Duchess of Connaught, according to the latest arrangements, are leaving Cairo on Tuesday afternoon next by special train, for Alexandria. His Royal High­ness will hold an inspection of the garrison on Wednesday, and the Royal party will leave on Thursday afternoon for Cyprus.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive spent yesterday at Koubbeh Palace.
His Highness will leave Cairo early next week for Montazah and will afterwards proceed to Mariont for his trip into the Libyan desert.

div.head: M. PUGNO'S RECITAL
div.p: M. Raoul Pugno’s recital, so long looked for ward to, came to pass last Tuesday before an overflowing audience. Seldom have we seen the large concert-hall of the New Khedivial Hotel so crowded, and by so intelligent and appreciative an audience. Some people be­forehand took exception to the fact that M. Pugno was unassisted by some vocalist, but hardly had this grand performer touched the keyboard than everyone was convinced that the programme of 15 items would be only too quickly finished. M. Pugno is justly consider­ed to have taken the place of Rubinstein in European fame, and yet itseems to us he is unknown in London, whither all the greatest artists congregate. His touch can only be compared in roundness, purity, and distinctness of tone to that of Kubelik, the greatest violinist of the day. For rapidity of finger combined with a limpid clearness—never a slur nor a false note—M. Pugno must be placed quite “hors de ligne.” Never has Weber’s "Hilarité” been heard given at such a pace, and yet with a perfect enunciation of every note. Power, energy, and dash are all qualities of this great pianist, but for breadth and depth Rubinstein excelled him, if not in correct passage playing and rapidity. Those who can recollect Rubinstein will remember that often in his most inspired moments, when his long hair fell over his cheek and his hands were raised above his head, wrong notes were often forgiven by his enthusiastic admirers, who almost worshipped him. The programme was divided into three parts. The first was dedicated to the older school, and M. Pugno played a most delightful selection from Bach, Handel, and Scarlatti, the pace of Bach’s Fugue and Handel’s Gavotte being simply marvellous. These three pieces he played without once touching the pedal. He then gave that chef d'œuvre of Beethoven known as the “Moonlight Sonata” to all music lovers,—one that every pupil attempts and usually murders!—On Tuesday night it was a magnificent performance from start to finish. The second part was entirely composed of Chopin’s music, and the first, three pieces were oldfavorites, familiar to all amateurs, and therefore an admirable lesson to the Con­servatoire pupils who were grouped at the back and sides of the platform. The Ballade in G Minor was a veritable “tour de force,” and the Polonaise which followed in E flat was amazing in its astonishing passages, where both hands seemed to be working in contrary and yet always bringing the composer’s ideas to a grand culminating finale. Part III. led off with Weber’s Hilarité, already mentioned, and then came two delightful little bits by Grieg. The one on Butterflies we thought wonderfully descriptive, and we heard distinctly the flutter of the fragile wings flapping more slowly when alighting on some winsome flower. M. Puguo then gave us an idea of his own compositions, the second of which we much preferred, the first being more difficult than beautiful. Lizst’s XIth. Rhapsodie was a strange exhibition of bis power over the strings of the instrument to produce reverberating echoes, and was more intended to astonish the ordinary concert-goer rather than edify the musician. The wild “gallop for the avenue” was a surprising demonstration of the strength and agility of this wonderful pianist. At the end the audience stood up and clapped and bravoed until he returned to acknowledge the heartiness of his reception in our city.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd' hui à midi et demie)

Aujourd’hui les valeurs égyptiennes sont en baisse à Londres. La Banque Nationale, entre autres, perd 1 livre en tombant d’un seul coup de 28 1/4 à 27 1/4. La raison de cette dégringolade provient d’importants ordres de ventes transmis du Caire à Londres. On veut,parait-il, se défaire ici des titres égyptiens pour em­ployer ses capitaux en fonds d’Ètat Étrangers qui vont sûrement hausser en prévision de la paix.

Aussi toute la cote est-elle en baisse sur notre place. Pour ne citer que les principales valeurs, la Banque Nationale tombe à 27 3/16, l'Agricole à 11 1/4, la Daïra à 25 1/16, la Delta Light à 14 3/8...
On croit que le marché reprendra bientôt.

div.head: LAND BANK OF EGYPT
div.p: The struggle on the Alexandria Bourse in regard to the Land Bank of Egypt has ended in the triumph of the party of the opposition, who have succeeded in keeping, for the present at all events, the shares of the bank from being officially quoted

At Tuesday's general meeting of the Alexandria Stockbrokers Association three-fourths of those present left the meeting as soon as the question of the Land Bank came up for discussion as they objected to voting by a show of hands instead of by a secret ballot. The dissentient were about fifty in number. Only four of those who remained had the courage to formally protest against the admission of the Bank. The remainder, about fifteen, accepted the quotation of the shares by a show of hands.

Immediately afterwards Mr. Rossano resigned his position on the committee of the association, as he disagreed with his fellow committeemen, and considered that the meeting had been irregularly composed, and that the proposition to admit the Bank had been irregularly presented as a report ought first to have been made. Yesterday two more important resignations followed, Mr. Alfred Campos vice-president of the association, and Mr. Caralli, another member of the committee having sent in their resignations.
The decision, arrived at on Tuesday, was annulled yesterday at the request of a number of influential stockbrokers, and the Land Bank is still not quoted.

div.head: ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
div.p: MIGNON

The performance at this theatre last evening of Thomas's Mignon is of especial interest; it is probably unique in the annals of operatic productions in Alexandria, or, for that matter, in Egypt, inasmuch that, included in the cast, were two of the brightest stars of the operatic world, in the persons of Signore Gemma Bellincioni and Isabella Svicher. The exceptional opportunity afforded to the theatre- going public by the enterprising management of this theatre was fully taken advantage of, for the house was crowded in every part and presented an animated appearance, the Governor of Alexandria being among the fashionable audience. The story of Mignon, which is founded on ‘‘Wilhelm Meister’s Apprenticeship,” by Goethe, is too well known to require any mention here, and those who were sufficiently fortunate to be able to witness last night’s performance will, we are confident, confirm our statement that a truer or more perfect presentation of this melodious opera would be well-nigh impossible. The pathetic character of Mignon, in the hands of such an accomplished artiste as Bellihcioni, was a creation not easily forgotten ; the great artiste s very presence proves magnetic, and the many charming arias allotted to the rôle were delivered with such a depth of feeling, such tenderness and artistic skill, that moved many to tears, and showed so clearly her delicate imaginative temperament and her exquisite sense of the value of light and shade ; her all consuming, self-effacing art was constantly in evidence. Signora Isabella Svicher’s performance in the rôle of Filina proved a revelation to many present, for frequently in productions of Mignon certain difficult passages and arias sung by Filina are entirely eliminated. It is unnecessary to say that last evening the opera was performed in its entirety, and the passages above referred ta were rendered with consummate skill by Signora Svicher, who was vociferously applauded repeatedly. Signora Bellincioni and Signora Svicher were admirably supported by Signor Tomisani, who scored a very distinct success in the rôle of Guglielmo. We have previously witnessed Signor Tomisani in this particular character, but never to better advantage than last evening, when his performance was worthy of the highest commendation, and was greatly appreciated. His sympathetic rendering of the charming romance “Addio Mignon” absolutely “brought down” the house. Signor Baldelli was again eminently successful in Lotario, his splendid voice being heard to great advantage. The other characters were in good hands, Signor Bodini making a sufficiently ferocious Laerte; The production, altogether, was one of the best it has ever been our pleasure to witness. The chorus worked well together, and the orchestra, tinder the able direction of Signor Donizetti, deserves every praise for its excellent performance.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB
div.p: THIRD WINTER MEETING

The afternoon of the K.S.C. races opened warm and calm, but the inevitable cold wind, with its accompaniment of flying straws and dust, got up at about 3 p.m., and rather spoiled the pleasure of those who were watching the sport. Preparations had been made for the arrival of the Duke and Duchess of Connaught, but their Royal Highnesses were unable after all to get to the races, though it is hoped that they will honor Friday’s meeting with their presence. Visitors were not very numerous at the races but there were many well-known residents in the grand-stand, among whom Maj.-General Slade, C.B., Mrs. And Miss Slade, Mr. M. de C. Findlay, C.M.G., Mr. Rumbold, Mr. Higgins, Count B. de Koskiedrowski, the Earl of Londesborough, Sir William Garstin, Coles Pasha, Mr. Carter Wilson, the Hon. F. O. Lindley, Maj. Garner, Mr. and Mrs. Astley Friend Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish, Mr. and Mrs. Hogg, Mr. and Mrs. Stout, Mr. Morice, Mme de Codt, Miss Rees, the Misses Hurley, Gen. and Mrs. Tyrell, Mr. and Mrs. Satow, Maj. Herbert, Mr. Tod, Mr. Moberley, Mr. and Mrs. Ray, Mr. Goschen, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Hewitt, Mr. Hayter, Omar Bey Sultan, Khalil Pasha, Khayat, Ishak Bey Hussein, G. Haddad Bey, and many others.

The racing was either very good or uncommonly bad, the horses winning by a head or by ten lengths. The fields ruled small, as did the payments, of the Pari Mutuel. In the first and last races Khalil Pasha Khayat scored victories, and Mr. Karam won the Grand National Steeplechase withSoudfi, well ridden by, Mr. Lockett, though the scratching of three horses out of six deprived the race of much of its interest. Roi de l'Air, in the fourth and Mabrouk, in the fifth race, ran away from the rest, but there could be no greater contrast than that presented by the two horses, Roi dé l’Air being a very pretty Arab while Mabrouk’s appearance could not be described as inviting. None the less he showed a rare turn of speed and started very quickly, as did Roi de l’Àir, getting right away from the rest in his first ten strides. The following are the results THE PALACE STAKES. Value L.E. 50, 2nd horse to receive L.E. 7, 3rd horse to receive L.E. 3, out of the stakes. A Handicap for Classes 1, 2, 3 and C.B.’s. Distance 7 furlongs. Alpha and Bonus got off first, Ibrahim Bey Cherif's horses tailing off pretty early. Bandusia was well up at the corner, where Bonus had passed Alpha and challenging him he got ahead after a close race by less than 1/2 length ; a poor third.

The Bard came up well at the corner, where all the horses except Gamechicken were close together, but on coming into the straight Mahmoud went ahead and the Bard could never quite catch him. On passing the grand-stand Mashkour, who had drawn up, pitched after clearing a hurdle and threw Fenwick, who was luckily not badly hurt. The other horses preserved their positions during the 2nd round, but on coming into the straight Mr. Lockett, riding with great judgement, got Soudfi in by ¼ length. A very popular victory.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves for the responsible opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit -- within certain necessary limits --free discussion.

div.head: INFANT MORTALITY IN EGYPT
div.p: To tee Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir, -- The discussion in your column on this subject led me re-read Mr. Lang Anderson’s remarks upon the subject. He says that the increase of population in the Khedive's dominions is far greater than in Europe, and that but for the excessive mortality this country would overflow with population. In making these reflections he does not seem to have taken all the circumstances into account. Egypt is by no means well populated at the present time. There is for instance a vast stretch of territory ranging from the confines of Alexandria to the Tripolitan frontier, which is practically desert though arable, and devoid of population. This was, in Roman times, the granary of Europe. Why might it not be so again with its virgin soil extending downwards several metres? And there is always the Sudan. In an article which appeared but a short time ago in the columns of the "Egyptian Gazette," entitled "Missions to Mohamedans," the writer described the African Sudan as about the size of Europe. Is there not space there for Egypt's surplus population? As regards that portion which is governed jointly by Egypt and England, it appears from Lord Cromer's latest report that the population is under two millions– it was estimated at eight and a half millions before the period of Dervish rule– and his lordship has no hope of any rapid increase. Indeed, so sparse is it, and so great the need of manual labor for its development that he announced his intention of considering the proposal of an American to import American negroes. We need therefore be in no hurry, it seems, to let Egyptian lives be wasted for fear of a glut in the labour market.– I am, etc.,
"Expansion."
Cairo, February 17.

div.head: Municipalité d’Alexandrie
div.p: TERRAINS DÉS QUAIS
Projet de reglement pour la vente des terrains de la Municipalité d'Alexandrie, arrete par les Co­mites des Finances et du Con­tentieux.
1er.— Les terrains de la Municipalité seront catalogués, et un prix dévaluation sera fixé pour chaque lot, par la Commission Muni­cipale, sur la proposition du Comité d'estimation.
Dans aucun cas, la vente de ces terrains ne pourra être faite à un prix inférieur à celui fixé par l’évaluation.
Ces prix pourront être révisés dans le pre­mier trimestre de chaque année.
Art. 2.— Les ventes s’effectueront par voie d’enchères ou de soumissions.
Toutefois, si, avant la mise en vente, le Gouvernement veut dans un but d’utilité géné­rale, acquérir un ou plusieurs lots, ils lui seront cédés au prix d’estimation du catalogue.
La cession pourra également se faire par voie d’échange.
Art. 3.— Les terrains seront vendus tels qu’ils se comportent, avec toutes leurs servitu­des actives et passives, et sans qu’aucun re­cours puisse être exercé, de ce chef, contre la Municipalité.

Art. 4.— Le prix d’achat sera payable : Vingt cinq pour cent, comptant et le solde en dix années, par fractions égales, avec intérêts à quatre pour cent par an, payables annuellement, à partir du 5e jour qui suivra l’adjudi­cation.

Art. 5.— La mise en vente sera portée à la connaissance du public, au moyen d’avis dans le Journal Officiel, et dans trois journaux d’Alexandrie, au moins. Ces avis seront égale­ment affichés à la Municipalité, au Gouvernorat et à la Bourse Khédiviale ; ils désigneront les lots mis en vente ; ils indiqueront leur numéro au catalogue et leur contenance, ainsi que leur mise à prix, forme de la mise en adjudication, et le jour et l’heure de la séance.
Art. 6.— Aucune personne ne pourra vala­blement concourir aux enchères sans avoir effectué au préalable, le versement d’un dépôt du 10 % de la mise à prix.
Ce dépôt ne portera aucun intérêt. Il pourra être versé jusqu’au moment de l’ouverture des enchères ou des soumissions.
Les enchérisseurs dont les offres n’auront pas été agréées, pourront retirer leurs dépôts dès le lendemain.

Art 7. — Toute offre implique, de plein droit, déclaration de connaissance du lot mis en vente, ainsi qu’adhésion au cahier des charges et aux dispositions du présent règlement. Elle devra être pure et simple ; l’offre qui exprime­rait une modalité serait considérée comme non avenue. Elle devra contenir une élection de domicile à Alexandrie, si l’enchérisseur ou sou­missionnaire n’y demeure pas. De même, l’en­chérisseur devenu adjudicataire, devra, s’il cesse de demeurer à Alexandrie, faire et com­muniquer une élection de domicile en la dite ville. Faute de ce faire et dans ces deux hypo­thèses, toute notification sera, de pacte express, valablement faite par la Municipalité, au greffe du tribunal mixte ou indigène d’Alex­andrie, selon la nationalité.

Art. 8.— Les acheteurs en commun, quelle que soit la quote-part de chacun d’eux, seront solidaires les uns des autres pour l’exécution de toutes les conditions de l’adjudication, et considérés comme une seule partie contrac­tante.

Art. 9.— Les séances d’enchères ou d’ou­verture des soumissions auront lieu à la Muni­cipalité au plus tôt trente jours après la publication des avis. Elles seront présidées par le Vice-Président de la Commission, eu par le Conseiller qui le suppléera, assisté de l’Admi­nistrateur. L’adjudication sera faite au profit du plus offrant ; au cas de plusieurs offres égales, il sera tiré au sort, séance tenante.
Art. 10.— Dans les cinq jours qui suivront, l’adjudicataire devra payer lé solde du premier terme, et consigner le montant des droits de transcription.
Art. 11.-- Il devra être passé acte authentique des ventes, aux Irais de l’acheteur, dans le mois qui suivra le paiement du solde du 1er terme.

Les actes de vente ne pourront être dressés qu’au nom de l’adjudicataire, à moins que celui-ci n’ait déclaré, au moment de la vente, qu’il agissait en qualité de mandataire et qu’il n’ait, en justifiant de cette qualité, fait connaitre le nom de son mandant, dont mention sera faite au procès-verbal d’adjudication.

Art. 12.—Les paiements doivent être faits à la Caisse Municipale où les fonds sont porta­bles. Au cas de non paiement exact et intégral du premier terme, dans le délai fixé à l’art 10, la Municipalité aura la faculté soit de considérer la vente comme définitivement résolue de plein droit, sans besoin de mise en demeure, et, en ce cas, le cautionnement deviendra la pro­priété de la Commission, à titre d’indemnité de résiliation d’après la présente clause pénale, soit de remettre le lot en vente, dans les mêmes formes, aux frais et pour compte de l’adjudica­taire, qui sera tenu de la différence d’avec le prix net d’adjudication et ses intérêts à quatre pour cent sur la totalité de ce prix, soit enfin, de poursuivre par les voies ordinaires l’exécu­tion des obligations de l’acheteur et, en ce der­nier cas, l’intérêt de retard courra de plein droit à sa charge au taux de cinq pour cent.

Au cas de retard dans le paiement de l’un des dix termes subséquents, dont le montant est également portable à la Caisse Municipale, l'intérêt de retard courra également de plein droit à cinq pour cent, sans préjudice des droits fixés par les art. 413 du Code Civil, et 334 du Code Civil Indigène.
Art. 13.— L’Administration consignera le terrain à l’adjudicataire dès le paiement du solde du 1er terme. Les bornes seront aux frais des acheteurs.
Les procès-verbaux de consignation seront faits en double, et seront signés par les

adjudicataires ou leurs représentants, ainsi que par les agents chargés de la consignation. Au cas où l’adjudicataire ne se présenterait pas, quoi­que invité, pour recevoir la consignation, le procès-verbal signé par les seuls agents de l’Administration vaudra délivrance définitive et consignation.

Art. 14.— Si le mesurage fait lors de la con­signation fait ressortir une différence de conte­nance, soit en plus, soit en moins, avec la con­tenance indiquée sur l’avis de mise en vente, le prix de vente sera augmenté ou diminué proportionnellement à la différence en plus ou en moins.
(à suivre)

div.head: ISLAM IN LONDON.
div.p: CREEDS AND IMPERIAL FEELING.

The Caxton Hall, London, on the 15th inst. did duty for the Mosque which all good Mohamedans hope some day to build in London. It was the day of Id-ai-Ad-ha, the Feast of Sacrifice, and at this season all good Mohamedans turn their thoughts towards Mecca. Here in London there were only two or three gathered together, and they represent­ed many races and nations of the Last, so much so that the address by Mr. Suhraworthy was spoken in English, that it might be understood of all.

Mr. Suhraworthy dwelt upon the fact that in the Mohamedan religion Abraham, called upon to slay his son and answering to the call, was the arch-type of sacrifice ; and he impress­ed upon his English hearers that there is far more in common between Christianity and Islam than most Christians dream. The ad­herents of both creeds worship one God, have listened to the same prophets, and have a common history behind them. The legends differ in detail. The Jews, who are descended from Isaac, believe that it was Isaac whom Abraham was called upon to slay ; the Arabs, for a similar reason, take Ishmael as the Lamb of Sacrifice. But the underlying principle is common to both faiths.

Self sacrifice is as much a cardinal point of the Mohamedan religion as it is of Christianity. The pilgrimage, in itself, is meant to inculcate the habit of sacrifice. Even to us, with the resources of civilisation, a long journey by rail or ship is a wearisome burden ; to the people of the East it means hardship, danger, and often death. On the long road to Mecca the merchant and the landlord have no wealth of goods or land ; they must compass each day a toilsome march, and at night time in the caravanserais it is a case of first come first served. No power of the purse will procure a better resting-place than the rest if the traveller comes late in the evening. On the desert road, if anywhere in the world, all men are equal.

This doctrine of self-sacrifice is so much part of our own religion that to find it insisted upon by the followers of Islam may surprise the majority of men who are accustomed to regard Mohamedanism as something much worse than heresy. And to the rank and file of Christ­ianity it would, perhaps, be a waste of time to attempt to teach the lesson that the differences between Islam and Christianity are in reality differences of degree rather than of kind, and not so very much greater, if they are greater at all the differences between the extreme sects of our own religion that to find it insisted upon by the followers of Islam may surprise the majority of men who are accustomed to regard Mohamedanism as something much worse than heresy. And to the rank and file of Christianity it would, perhaps, be a waste of time to attempt to teach the lesson that the differences between Islam and Christianity are in reality differences of degree rather than of kind, and not so very much greater, if they are greater at all, than differences between the extreme sects of our own faith.

Yet, to the more thoughtful student of ethics, it must be apparent that much good can come of the attempt to insist rather Upon the points of agreement than upon the points of difference. We have at this moment over sixty million Mohamedans in the British Empire, and it may be said without offence that Mohamedans have learned toler­ation through contact with British institutions. A Christian can walk freely into any mosque in India ; but he carries his life in his hands if he starts for Mecca.

But if the Mohamedans within the Empire have learned toleration from our institutions, we, too, have something to learn in breadth of view and in sympathy. The Pan-Islamic Society is endeavouring to do something towards teaching us that lesson. The work is not easy. because so few people can be brought to listen to argument or dissertation ; yet it is a work that should not be despised. The breaking- down of needless barriers, and the encouragement of those who insist upon the breadth of the Mohamedan faith and its likeness to Christianity, will do more than anything else to strengthen the bonds of the British Empire in the East. (Home paper).

div.head: TAHTA NOTES
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Tahta, Feb. 20.

Lord and Lady Cromer called at Tahta on the 18th inst. at 4.30 p.m, en route from Nag Hamadi. His lordship’s arrival was only noticed when the postal agent was seen going down to the river carrying the mail to his lordship. The Mamour of the Markaz no sooner got wind of the arrival of the distinguished party than he hastened with a police force to be in attendance on them.

The Mamour met Lord and Lady Cromer walking on the Nile bank leading to the town. They were good enough to shake hands with him, and showed themselves grateful for his attention. His lordship said that he did not like to be welcomed with any ceremony and asked only for some ghaffirs. Ten ghaffirs were therefore sent down to the river. At 6 p.m. next day, Lord Cromer left for Manfalout.

Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior arrived here on Wednesday on a tour of inspection. He was accompanied by Mr. Russell and two other Englishmen. They arrived from Assiout by steamer. Mr. Machell spoke with the Mamour on various subjects connected with public security. The Mamour told the Adviser that he was fully satisfied with the new scheme of the Ministry of the Interior, whereby ten ghaffir officers were appointed for Tahta district. The scheme in question has had good results, as when these officers are on their nightly rounds they arrest thieves escaping away with their booty. Mr. Machell went to see the new Markaz buildings, which are nearly finished.
For the last three weeks no less than nine serious crimes were committed in this district. One was a case of murder, the rest being chiefly highway robberies, camel thefts, etc,

div.head: EGYPTIAN MONEY MARKET
div.p: THE RECENT HOISTING OF PRICES PREMATURE?

“The Financier” remarks :—That things are humming in Egypt may be granted, but there is a distinct tendency to overdo the hoisting of prices. The accounts of the National Bank of Egypt are not due to be published for a month or so, but we have excellent reasons for believing that when they see the light they will contain nothing to justify a quotation of 27 for the £10 shares. The fact is, Egyptian progress has, of late, been so remarkable that the public and the market have got a little dazzled by the glare of bright prospects and still brighter possibilities. Anything which would have the effect of adjusting a pair of blue spectacles over the speculative nose, too eager to sniff fat profits, would be highly salu­tary. The National Bank’s interest in the Agri­cultural Bank is a factor not to be forgotten, and the latter concern is getting along very comfortably ; but, allowing for all that, prices are too high, and it would be a wholesome thing to have a gentle set-back before they go higher.

Respecting the Daira Sanieh, whose shares are also exhibiting a skyward movement, the circumstances are certainly peculiar, and there is perhaps more excuse for the boomlet. Mainly owing to the energetic administration of Sir William Willcock8, the managing director, the whole of the vast domain has been sold at a splendid profit. In October, in accordance with the scheme formulated, the original bonds will be paid off, and the profits accruing on this gigantic land agency business will be divided equally between the Daira Sanieh Company and the Egyptian Government.

Now that the head office has been removed from London to Cairo (a very, sensible proceeding no doubt, seeing that practically the whole of the business of the company is carried on in Egypt), the accounts are made up in Cairo. They will, so we are informed, be ready some time in March. They will show that the whole object and purpose of forming the company— that is, the sale of the Daira Sanieh estates on behalf of the Government—has for all practical purposes been already performed. When the time comes for the formal completion of the business in October, little will have to be done but to receive the cash due from about 700 purchasers, hand over half the profit to the Comptrollers, representing the Government, and distribute the other half.

For the most part the tenants—the fellaheen now cultivating the Daira Sanieh lands, which are already irrigated, will remain as owners. The inception, development and rea­lisation of this great scheme, which will appreciate the value of the land concerned by mil­lions of pounds sterling, is full of interest to the student of economics, as well as to the financier. The secret of the substantial profits which have been realised can be written in one word—irrigation. The lands are all so situated that irrigation from the Nile is comparatively easy. The system of pumping is simple, and now that the great barrage is finished, ample water will always be available, whatever fluctuation the seasons may bring.

Until the accounts of the company are published, or their salient features disclosed, it is, of course, impossible to appraise the value of the company’s securities, but the Deferred shares at 143 should not be bought without inside knowledge.

div.head: CAIRO AGRICULTURAL SHOW
div.p: The exhibits of Messrs. Hassabo Mohamed & Co., Alexandria, at the Cairo Agricultural Show, include a quantity of machinery made by Messrs. Davey, Paxman & Co., Ld., Col­chester, for whom Messrs. Hassabo & Co. are the sole agents for Egypt and the Sudan. These are :—1 producer gas engine, to work by anthracite coal (new pattern) ; 2 compound portable engines, 2 compound fixed engines (Colchester & Tandem). 1 economic steam boiler, 1 steam cultivator : the Darby land digger ; 7 centrifugal pumps (different sizes). 1 gigantic wind pump, 1 pump that can be turned by animals, several hand-pumps for wells, 1 iron sakieh,2 sugar-cane pressing-mills, several bean mills, several norags, 2 flour mills (3 1/2 ft. diameter), cranes and pulley-blocks forges (different kinds), belting, and tools.

The Cairo Sewage Transport Company are exhibiting in the central hall the various descrip­tions of their natural organic manures which, since the commencement of their manufacture, have obtained for themselves such distinctive success in this country. Besides their “pou- drette” manures, which are found to be so highly suitable to all soils and crops without reserve, forming a perfect organic fertiliser, it is noteworthy that this company within recent years has united to its ordinary productions that of the scientific treatment of all the resi­dues obtained from the Cairo Abattoir, and also the tanneries. This gives an excellent manure at a reasonable price, and is distributed in very large quantities all over the country. Among the landowners patronising the company, we may mention the Daira of H.H. the Khedive, Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, Riaz Pasha, Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmy, the Daira Draneht Pasha, and many others comprising all the most important Egyptian agriculturists.

div.head: ARCTOWSKA CONCERT
div.p: We had the pleasure of hearing Mme. Arctowska on Friday at the Savoy Hotel. The programme consisted wholly of songs—16 items. The interest of it can be judged by the fact that it began with Carissimi and ended with Richard Strauss, and included Grieg, Humperdinck, Schubert, Brahms (to quote only a few). Mme. Arctowska has a most pleasing and thoroughly well-trained voice : at moments it is a little hard in the “forte” effects, but in her pianissimo notes and for general flexibility and sweetness of tone, she was delightful. The “Dustman,” by Molloy, she gave almost from start to finish in what we can only call “sordini,” thereby transforming a rather commonplace production into a real pleasure. We can hardly hope to criticise the 16 details, and so we state our preferences ; the Carissimi had that delightful “finish” which makes that period so attractive; “Polly Willis,” by Arne, is a treasure and shows how English music could once upon a time compete with any for its own peculiar vigour and fresh ness; the Grieg (“La Princesse”) has all that intimate northern suggestion (at its best) which makes Grieg such a personality in music. “Bergère Légère” (Inconnu) has a touch of Gounod (that of “O ma belle rebelle”), but is quite free from that ecclesiastical eroticism which displeases so many in him. The Strauss, with its curiously dreamy, and highly individual treatment, set one thinking. Strauss is, it seems, setting the musical world “by the ears,” and no wonder ; tor whatever his “Life of a Hero” may be in its effect, he is at least a new departure, not cowed by reminiscence into commonplace. We need not waste space by reiterating the delight of the Feldeinsamheit and the Schubert Bongs. We repeat that the whole selection and its arrange­ment showed thorough taste and knowledge, and was indeed exceptional ; so often in such concerts one has to be content with two or three good songs and a host of second-rate items. Mme. Arctowska knows how to choose her songs, and how to sing them. M. Valentino was an admirable accompanist ; we hope he will accept the compliment we intend in that we remind our readers of his excellence and brilliance as a soloist on the piano. It was a great pleasure to hear a Bluthner piano, perhaps the one piano exactly suited to the programme and the room. One word as to the latter ; it is indeed hard on the performers to have to accept the accommodation possible in Cairo ; the average room provided in the hotels (much as we love our hotels) is a trial ; resonance is impossible, and the environment is the more trying to the performers. For all that, it was a great treat to hear so interesting a programme so well rendered ; and we tender our compliments and thanks to Madame Arctowska.

div.head: NEEDED NEW BLOOD.
div.p: DR. WILLIAMS’ PINK PILLS MADE NEW BLOOD.

“My daughter came home ill at the end of last year, and day by day she. faded away until I had lost all hope for her,” said Mrs. Barr, of Toft-lane, West Rasen, to a reporter of the Lincolnshire Chronicle. “They were dark days for us. My daughter had had medicine enough. What she wanted was new blood. She seemed to have no strength left, and doctors said her illness was Rheumatic Fever and Anaemia. For three weeks she could not turn herself in bed. Then she took Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills, and if she had not she would not be here now. After one box she was out of bed.”

Miss Barr is now the very type of bright, healthy young womanhood, and there is no doubt that without the new blood which Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills gave her, she would have sunk into a Decline and died. Women know why they and their daughters need new blood more than men; but men can be Anaemic, too. The weak back, easy fatigue, lack of interest in life, indigestion, and general nervous weak­ness which trouble both men and women, need new blood to cure them, and these pills make new blood. Nerves that need new blood to feed them show their need in Neuralgia, Fits, St. Vitus’ Dance, eventually Paralysis, Locomotor Ataxy, and utter breakdown. But Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills for Pale People can cure all these things—the genuine pills. div.p: La Société des Eaux du Caire porte à la connaissance du Public, que son installation pour la distribution des Eaux à Koub-beh-Zeitoun et Matarieh étant achevée, elle est prête à fournir dans les dites localités, l'ean pour la consommation, arrosage des jardins, chantiers de constructions et tous autres besoins.
Toute demande de concession devra Être faite par lettre à l’adresse du Directeur de la Société des Eaux du Caire.
Le tarif du prix de l’eau dans les dites localités, tant par abonnement fixe que par compteur, est à la disposition du public, dans les Bureaux de la Société Avenue de-Boulac au Caire.

La Société est prête à établir ses canalisations d'eau dans les rues non pourvues de conduites, lorsqu’elle aura reçu des demandes suffisantes de concession pour une même rue.— Les habitants de Konbbeb, Zeitoun et Matarieh sont donc priés de présenter leur demandes par groupes résidant dans une même rue, afin de permettre à la Société d'examiner sans retard leurs demandes,__en vue de canaliser et de leur accorder des concessions d'eau.
Le Caire, le 23 Janvier 1905.
Le Directeur,
25329-40*-5 „ Astley P. Friend.

div.head: ISLAM IN LONDON.
div.p: CREEDS AND IMPERIAL FEELING.

The Caxton Hall, London, on the 15th inst. did duty for the Mosque which all good Mohamedans hope some day to build in London. It was the day of Id-ai-Ad-ha, the Feast of Sacrifice, and at this season all good Mohamedans turn their thoughts towards Mecca. Here in London there were only two or three gathered together, and they represent­ed many races and nations of the Last, so much so that the address by Mr. Suhraworthy was spoken in English, that it might be understood of all.

Mr. Suhraworthy dwelt upon the fact that in the Mohamedan religion Abraham, called upon to slay his son and answering to the call, was the arch-type of sacrifice ; and he impress­ed upon his English hearers that there is far more in common between Christianity and Islam than most Christians dream. The ad­herents of both creeds worship one God, have listened to the same prophets, and have a common history behind them. The legends differ in detail. The Jews, who are descended from Isaac, believe that it was Isaac whom Abraham was called upon to slay ; the Arabs, for a similar reason, take Ishmael as the Lamb of Sacrifice. But the underlying principle is common to both faiths.

Self sacrifice is as much a cardinal point of the Mohamedan religion as it is of Christianity. The pilgrimage, in itself, is meant to inculcate the habit of sacrifice. Even to us, with the resources of civilisation, a long journey by rail or ship is a wearisome burden ; to the people of the East it means hardship, danger, and often death. On the long road to Mecca the merchant and the landlord have no wealth of goods or land ; they must compass each day a toilsome march, and at night time in the caravanserais it is a case of first come first served. No power of the purse will procure a better resting-place than the rest if the traveller comes late in the evening. On the desert road, if anywhere in the world, all men are equal.

This doctrine of self-sacrifice is so much part of our own religion that to find it insisted upon by the followers of Islam may surprise the majority of men who are accustomed to regard Mohamedanism as something much worse than heresy. And to the rank and file of Christ­ianity it would, perhaps, be a waste of time to attempt to teach the lesson that the differences between Islam and Christianity are in reality differences of degree rather than of kind, and not so very much greater, if they are greater at all the differences between the extreme sects of our own religion that to find it insisted upon by the followers of Islam may surprise the majority of men who are accustomed to regard Mohamedanism as something much worse than heresy. And to the rank and file of Christianity it would, perhaps, be a waste of time to attempt to teach the lesson that the differences between Islam and Christianity are in reality differences of degree rather than of kind, and not so very much greater, if they are greater at all, than differences between the extreme sects of our own faith.

Yet, to the more thoughtful student of ethics, it must be apparent that much good can come of the attempt to insist rather Upon the points of agreement than upon the points of difference. We have at this moment over sixty million Mohamedans in the British Empire, and it may be said without offence that Mohamedans have learned toler­ation through contact with British institutions. A Christian can walk freely into any mosque in India ; but he carries his life in his hands if he starts for Mecca.

But if the Mohamedans within the Empire have learned toleration from our institutions, we, too, have something to learn in breadth of view and in sympathy. The Pan-Islamic Society is endeavouring to do something towards teaching us that lesson. The work is not easy. because so few people can be brought to listen to argument or dissertation ; yet it is a work that should not be despised. The breaking- down of needless barriers, and the encouragement of those who insist upon the breadth of the Mohamedan faith and its likeness to Christianity, will do more than anything else to strengthen the bonds of the British Empire in the East. (Home paper).

div.head: TAHTA NOTES
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Tahta, Feb. 20.

Lord and Lady Cromer called at Tahta on the 18th inst. at 4.30 p.m, en route from Nag Hamadi. His lordship’s arrival was only noticed when the postal agent was seen going down to the river carrying the mail to his lordship. The Mamour of the Markaz no sooner got wind of the arrival of the distinguished party than he hastened with a police force to be in attendance on them.

The Mamour met Lord and Lady Cromer walking on the Nile bank leading to the town. They were good enough to shake hands with him, and showed themselves grateful for his attention. His lordship said that he did not like to be welcomed with any ceremony and asked only for some ghaffirs. Ten ghaffirs were therefore sent down to the river. At 6 p.m. next day, Lord Cromer left for Manfalout.

Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior arrived here on Wednesday on a tour of inspection. He was accompanied by Mr. Russell and two other Englishmen. They arrived from Assiout by steamer. Mr. Machell spoke with the Mamour on various subjects connected with public security. The Mamour told the Adviser that he was fully satisfied with the new scheme of the Ministry of the Interior, whereby ten ghaffir officers were appointed for Tahta district. The scheme in question has had good results, as when these officers are on their nightly rounds they arrest thieves escaping away with their booty. Mr. Machell went to see the new Markaz buildings, which are nearly finished.
For the last three weeks no less than nine serious crimes were committed in this district. One was a case of murder, the rest being chiefly highway robberies, camel thefts, etc,

div.head: EGYPTIAN MONEY MARKET
div.p: THE RECENT HOISTING OF PRICES PREMATURE?

“The Financier” remarks :—That things are humming in Egypt may be granted, but there is a distinct tendency to overdo the hoisting of prices. The accounts of the National Bank of Egypt are not due to be published for a month or so, but we have excellent reasons for believing that when they see the light they will contain nothing to justify a quotation of 27 for the £10 shares. The fact is, Egyptian progress has, of late, been so remarkable that the public and the market have got a little dazzled by the glare of bright prospects and still brighter possibilities. Anything which would have the effect of adjusting a pair of blue spectacles over the speculative nose, too eager to sniff fat profits, would be highly salu­tary. The National Bank’s interest in the Agri­cultural Bank is a factor not to be forgotten, and the latter concern is getting along very comfortably ; but, allowing for all that, prices are too high, and it would be a wholesome thing to have a gentle set-back before they go higher.

Respecting the Daira Sanieh, whose shares are also exhibiting a skyward movement, the circumstances are certainly peculiar, and there is perhaps more excuse for the boomlet. Mainly owing to the energetic administration of Sir William Willcock8, the managing director, the whole of the vast domain has been sold at a splendid profit. In October, in accordance with the scheme formulated, the original bonds will be paid off, and the profits accruing on this gigantic land agency business will be divided equally between the Daira Sanieh Company and the Egyptian Government.

Now that the head office has been removed from London to Cairo (a very, sensible proceeding no doubt, seeing that practically the whole of the business of the company is carried on in Egypt), the accounts are made up in Cairo. They will, so we are informed, be ready some time in March. They will show that the whole object and purpose of forming the company— that is, the sale of the Daira Sanieh estates on behalf of the Government—has for all practical purposes been already performed. When the time comes for the formal completion of the business in October, little will have to be done but to receive the cash due from about 700 purchasers, hand over half the profit to the Comptrollers, representing the Government, and distribute the other half.

For the most part the tenants—the fellaheen now cultivating the Daira Sanieh lands, which are already irrigated, will remain as owners. The inception, development and rea­lisation of this great scheme, which will appreciate the value of the land concerned by mil­lions of pounds sterling, is full of interest to the student of economics, as well as to the financier. The secret of the substantial profits which have been realised can be written in one word—irrigation. The lands are all so situated that irrigation from the Nile is comparatively easy. The system of pumping is simple, and now that the great barrage is finished, ample water will always be available, whatever fluctuation the seasons may bring.

Until the accounts of the company are published, or their salient features disclosed, it is, of course, impossible to appraise the value of the company’s securities, but the Deferred shares at 143 should not be bought without inside knowledge.

div.head: CAIRO AGRICULTURAL SHOW
div.p: The exhibits of Messrs. Hassabo Mohamed & Co., Alexandria, at the Cairo Agricultural Show, include a quantity of machinery made by Messrs. Davey, Paxman & Co., Ld., Col­chester, for whom Messrs. Hassabo & Co. are the sole agents for Egypt and the Sudan. These are :—1 producer gas engine, to work by anthracite coal (new pattern) ; 2 compound portable engines, 2 compound fixed engines (Colchester & Tandem). 1 economic steam boiler, 1 steam cultivator : the Darby land digger ; 7 centrifugal pumps (different sizes). 1 gigantic wind pump, 1 pump that can be turned by animals, several hand-pumps for wells, 1 iron sakieh,2 sugar-cane pressing-mills, several bean mills, several norags, 2 flour mills (3 1/2 ft. diameter), cranes and pulley-blocks forges (different kinds), belting, and tools.

The Cairo Sewage Transport Company are exhibiting in the central hall the various descrip­tions of their natural organic manures which, since the commencement of their manufacture, have obtained for themselves such distinctive success in this country. Besides their “pou- drette” manures, which are found to be so highly suitable to all soils and crops without reserve, forming a perfect organic fertiliser, it is noteworthy that this company within recent years has united to its ordinary productions that of the scientific treatment of all the resi­dues obtained from the Cairo Abattoir, and also the tanneries. This gives an excellent manure at a reasonable price, and is distributed in very large quantities all over the country. Among the landowners patronising the company, we may mention the Daira of H.H. the Khedive, Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, Riaz Pasha, Prince Ibrahim Pasha Hilmy, the Daira Draneht Pasha, and many others comprising all the most important Egyptian agriculturists.

div.head: ARCTOWSKA CONCERT
div.p: We had the pleasure of hearing Mme. Arctowska on Friday at the Savoy Hotel. The programme consisted wholly of songs—16 items. The interest of it can be judged by the fact that it began with Carissimi and ended with Richard Strauss, and included Grieg, Humperdinck, Schubert, Brahms (to quote only a few). Mme. Arctowska has a most pleasing and thoroughly well-trained voice : at moments it is a little hard in the “forte” effects, but in her pianissimo notes and for general flexibility and sweetness of tone, she was delightful. The “Dustman,” by Molloy, she gave almost from start to finish in what we can only call “sordini,” thereby transforming a rather commonplace production into a real pleasure. We can hardly hope to criticise the 16 details, and so we state our preferences ; the Carissimi had that delightful “finish” which makes that period so attractive; “Polly Willis,” by Arne, is a treasure and shows how English music could once upon a time compete with any for its own peculiar vigour and fresh ness; the Grieg (“La Princesse”) has all that intimate northern suggestion (at its best) which makes Grieg such a personality in music. “Bergère Légère” (Inconnu) has a touch of Gounod (that of “O ma belle rebelle”), but is quite free from that ecclesiastical eroticism which displeases so many in him. The Strauss, with its curiously dreamy, and highly individual treatment, set one thinking. Strauss is, it seems, setting the musical world “by the ears,” and no wonder ; tor whatever his “Life of a Hero” may be in its effect, he is at least a new departure, not cowed by reminiscence into commonplace. We need not waste space by reiterating the delight of the Feldeinsamheit and the Schubert Bongs. We repeat that the whole selection and its arrange­ment showed thorough taste and knowledge, and was indeed exceptional ; so often in such concerts one has to be content with two or three good songs and a host of second-rate items. Mme. Arctowska knows how to choose her songs, and how to sing them. M. Valentino was an admirable accompanist ; we hope he will accept the compliment we intend in that we remind our readers of his excellence and brilliance as a soloist on the piano. It was a great pleasure to hear a Bluthner piano, perhaps the one piano exactly suited to the programme and the room. One word as to the latter ; it is indeed hard on the performers to have to accept the accommodation possible in Cairo ; the average room provided in the hotels (much as we love our hotels) is a trial ; resonance is impossible, and the environment is the more trying to the performers. For all that, it was a great treat to hear so interesting a programme so well rendered ; and we tender our compliments and thanks to Madame Arctowska.

div.head: NEEDED NEW BLOOD.
div.p: DR. WILLIAMS’ PINK PILLS MADE NEW BLOOD.

“My daughter came home ill at the end of last year, and day by day she. faded away until I had lost all hope for her,” said Mrs. Barr, of Toft-lane, West Rasen, to a reporter of the Lincolnshire Chronicle. “They were dark days for us. My daughter had had medicine enough. What she wanted was new blood. She seemed to have no strength left, and doctors said her illness was Rheumatic Fever and Anaemia. For three weeks she could not turn herself in bed. Then she took Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills, and if she had not she would not be here now. After one box she was out of bed.”

Miss Barr is now the very type of bright, healthy young womanhood, and there is no doubt that without the new blood which Dr. Williams’ Pink Pills gave her, she would have sunk into a Decline and died. Women know why they and their daughters need new blood more than men; but men can be Anaemic, too. div.head: THE DEADLY MOSQUITO
div.p: "It is sufficient to my Protection from the Mosquito Bites affords complete immunity in ague in all its forms... Yellow fever, like Ague, has been shown to be communicated only by a mosquito." - Times, 30th, September, 1904.
Against this deadly insect science has at last provided us with a protection in the shape of
ANTIKITO CREAM (Regd.)

This wonderful preparation – which is most delightfully refreshing to use – is the outcome of long laboratory research. During the last five years it has been thoroughly tested in all parts of the world. By its use the fatal mosquito, as well as flies, gnats, and all flying insects, are set at defiance. It is absolutely infallible as a preventive, and is guaranteed to be free from carbolic and other deleterions ingredients. It is neither sticky nor greasy and one application to the exposed parts affords protection for hours. Invaluable for hospital use, and should be in the kit of all expeditions. It is better than Quinine. Protects you from flies
ANTIKITO CREAM is manufactured under expert supervision in the Syndicate's own laboratory, and is put up in two sizes. Proprietors:
ANTIKITO SYNDICATE, LTD.,
G. Great Portland Street, LONDON.
N.B.– A most interesting and instructive booklet, entitled – "THE MOSQUITO AND SOMETHING ABOUT HIM," will be sent free to anyone applying for it.
